trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - Successfully demonstrated on lunar surface during Firefly Blue Ghost Mission 1 (landed March 2, 2025, concluded March 16, 2025). NASA official source.
trl.notes: Successfully demonstrated on lunar surface during Firefly Blue Ghost Mission 1, March 2025

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked NASA.gov sources, NTRS, science.gov. Mass depends on application surface area.
mass_kg.notes: Mass depends on application surface area; not published for specific configurations

power_kw.verification_notes: Confirmed low power operation - 2 microampere current per science.gov. Estimate of 0.001 kW is reasonable for microampere-level operation.
power_kw.notes: Low power in mA range, voltage 1-4 kV, current in microampere range

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly priced. NASA-developed technology available through technology transfer program. Checked NASA.gov and tech transfer sources.
cost_usd.notes: NASA-developed technology, not commercially priced. Tech transfer/licensing may be available

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA.gov - Available through NASA technology transfer program, not off-the-shelf.
procurement_lead_time.notes: Available through NASA technology transfer program; not off-the-shelf product

performance.verification_notes: Corrected from 75-100% to 90-99%. Multiple sources confirm: 92%+ in vacuum (science.gov), 96-99% for reflective surfaces, 80-95% for spacesuit materials, 90%+ typical performance.
performance.notes: 90-99% in vacuum testing. Uses three-phase electrodes generating non-uniform electric field

items.application: Solar panels, thermal radiators, camera lenses, optical equipment, helmet visors
items.notes: Developed over 18+ years at KSC Electrostatics and Surface Physics Laboratory. Considered best non-contact active dust mitigation technology. Two configurations: copper on Kapton for radiators, ITO on glass for optics.

trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 6 to TRL 4. Confirmed Phase I SBIR project. Phase I typically achieves TRL 3-4 (component validation in laboratory). No evidence of Phase II completion or TRL 6 achievement found.
trl.notes: Phase I SBIR project, estimated TRL 4 based on development phase

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked SBIR sources, NASA databases. Laminate weight depends on surface area covered.
mass_kg.notes: Laminate weight depends on surface area covered

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. Lower power than EDS alone claimed (dust transported in air vs along surface), but specific values not available in SBIR or NASA sources.
power_kw.notes: Lower power than EDS alone (dust transported in air vs along surface), specific values not published

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. SBIR Phase I funded development, commercial pricing not yet established.
cost_usd.notes: SBIR-funded development, commercial pricing not yet established

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed Phase I SBIR project from sbir.gov. Still in development, not commercially available.
procurement_lead_time.notes: Active SBIR project, not yet commercially available

performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from SBIR source - combines vibration, electrodynamic force, and superhydrophobic surface. Claims more effective than EDS alone as dust transported in air rather than along surface.
performance.notes: Combines vibration, electrodynamic force, and superhydrophobic surface. Vibration effective for uncharged/large particles. Real-time dust monitoring via force sensor

items.application: Solar panels, camera lenses, spacecraft viewports, spacesuit fabrics, rotary joints, connectors
items.notes: Three-mechanism approach more effective than single-method systems. Similar structure to EDS enabling fast manufacturing/installation. Electroactive polymer layer functions as force sensor for smart dust removal.

items.vendor: NASA JPL / University of Colorado Boulder (LASP)
items.model: Moon Duster / Electron Beam Dust Mitigation (EBDM)

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 6. NASA TechLeap Prize awarded 2025, parabolic flight testing scheduled summer 2026. Consistent with TRL 6 (fully functional prototype).
trl.notes: Estimated TRL 6 based on TechLeap Prize award (2025) and development stage

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Handheld device but specific mass not available in LASP or NASA sources.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. Electron beam device but power requirements not specified in available sources.
power_kw.notes: Power requirements not published; electron beam device

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not commercially priced. Developed by Space Dust Research & Technologies LLC with NASA TechLeap Prize ($500k award).
cost_usd.notes: NASA TechLeap Prize funded, not commercially priced

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed from LASP source. Parabolic flight testing scheduled summer 2026. Active development, not commercially available.
procurement_lead_time.notes: Active development, TechLeap Prize winner continuing work, parabolic flight test summer 2026

performance.verification_notes: Corrected from 75-85% to up to 92%. Earlier research (2020) showed 75-85%, improved to 92% by 2025 per LASP source. Tested on spacesuits, solar panels, optical lenses, thermal blankets.
performance.notes: Up to 92% dust removal across various surfaces (2025). Uses electron beams to charge and repel lunar dust. Earlier tests (2020) showed 75-85%.

items.application: Spacesuits, hardware surfaces, equipment cleaning - any dust-covered space hardware
items.notes: Standalone handheld device - no embedded layers required. Major advantage over EDS: can be used on existing hardware without modification. Charges dust particles to cause repulsion and removal.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5 from NASA.gov source. NASA-selected university research program for lunar dust mitigation.
trl.notes: Estimated TRL 4-5 based on NASA university program selection and research phase

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Piezoelectric actuator mass depends on solar cell size.
mass_kg.notes: Piezoelectric actuators, mass depends on solar cell size

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. Power for piezoelectric actuators not specified in available sources.
power_kw.notes: Power for piezoelectric actuators not specified

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. University research project, no commercial pricing.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed from ScienceDirect publication. NASA-funded university research, not yet productized.
procurement_lead_time.notes: NASA-funded university research, not yet productized

performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from ScienceDirect peer-reviewed publication. Performance varies with dust loading.
performance.notes: Efficiency varies with dust loading: 60.8% at 1.07 mg/cm² down to 33.6% at 16.37 mg/cm². Performance decreases as dust accumulates. Enhanced when combined with electrostatic forces

items.notes: Piezoelectric actuators bonded to inactive side of solar cells. Auto-detects dust accumulation and activates. Surface acceleration overcomes adhesive forces. Sol-gel surface treatments reduce Van der Waals forces. Can be combined with EDS for improved performance.

trl.notes: TRL 5 cited in Phase 1 research, passive coating in development/testing
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5 from NASA SBIR source. Phase I research, passive coating in development/testing.

mass_kg.notes: Coating - negligible mass added to substrate

power_kw.verification_notes: Confirmed zero power from ScienceDirect. Passive coating technology.

procurement_lead_time.notes: Under development at GSFC, not commercially available
procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed development stage from NASA SBIR sources.

performance.notes: Reduces surface energy and attachment area. Self-cleaning properties shed dust particles. Anti-contamination characteristics minimize accumulation
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from ScienceDirect. High scoring passive technology in comprehensive review.

items.application: Spacecraft surfaces, thermal control, general dust accumulation prevention
items.notes: Mimics lotus leaf self-cleaning properties. Passive approach requires no external stimulus. Being developed for long-duration human exploration countermeasure.

trl.notes: TRL 5-6 estimated based on development for rigid surfaces
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5-6 from NASA NTRS publication.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Coating technology, minimal mass.

power_kw.verification_notes: Confirmed zero power from NASA NTRS. Passive conductive coating.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. Coating technology, minimal mass.

performance.notes: Transparent conductive coating reduces dust adhesion and dissipates surface charge. Passive charge dissipation prevents electrostatic accumulation

items.notes: Simple transparent conductive coating for rigid surfaces. Work function matching reduces adhesion. Charge dissipation prevents electrostatic dust buildup. Passive technology developed by NASA GRC.

trl.notes: Phase II Sequential award $3.2M (2024) for prototype bearings, indicating TRL 6-7
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 7. Phase II Sequential award $3.2M (2024-2026) per NASA.gov. Prototype bearings in development.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked NASA and ATSP sources.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. Checked NASA and ATSP sources.

procurement_lead_time.notes: Phase II Sequential contract ongoing for prototype development
procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA.gov. Prototype development 2024-2026 per Phase II contract.

performance.value: Superior abrasive wear resistance vs PEEK
performance.notes: Excellent wear resistance in presence of lunar dust simulant against 440C steel. Particularly effective with <38 µm dust. Higher abrasive wear resistance than PEEK coating
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from ScienceDirect peer-reviewed paper. Superior wear resistance vs PEEK.

items.application: Bearings for lunar rovers, mechanisms, robotic joints, rotating equipment
items.notes: Aromatic thermosetting copolyester (vitrimer) - cross-links like thermoset, reprocessable like thermoplastic. Tg >250°C, stable to 500°C. Operational -220°C to 300°C. Corrosion and wear resistance. Available as powder, molding compound, or bulk solids.

items.model: Dust Resisting Secondary Emission TCMS Coating

trl.notes: Phase II Sequential award $2.6M (2024), indicating TRL 6-7
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA.gov. Phase II Sequential $2.6M award (2024).

power_kw.notes: Passive coating for thermal control, no power required

cost_usd.notes: Development stage, commercial pricing not established

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA.gov. Phase II Sequential $2.6M award (2024).

performance.notes: Integration of dust-resisting properties with secondary emission engineered passive thermal control material systems
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA.gov. Phase II Sequential $2.6M award (2024).

items.application: Thermal control surfaces on rovers, landers, equipment
items.notes: Addresses critical Apollo lesson: dust on thermal radiators caused battery overheating. Combines dust resistance with thermal control functionality. Location: Streamwood, Illinois.

items.vendor: Texas Tech University / NASA Johnson Space Center

trl.notes: SBIR Phase I completed (2021), estimated TRL 4-5
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA SBIR and university sources. Phase I completed 2021.

power_kw.notes: Active vibration system requires power, specific consumption not published

procurement_lead_time.notes: Phase I completed, further development needed
procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA SBIR and university sources. Phase I completed 2021.

performance.value: Optimized modal vibration with passive coating
performance.notes: Uses vibrational excitation at targeted modal frequencies. Assisted by passive dust mitigation coatings. Addresses Apollo 17 LRV radiator dust problem
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA SBIR and university sources. Phase I completed 2021.

items.application: Thermal radiators, particularly for lunar rovers
items.notes: Specifically targets thermal radiator dust buildup that caused Apollo 17 LRV battery overheating. Tested with standard and custom lunar highland dust simulants. Active/passive hybrid approach.

trl.notes: TechPort project 113118, variant of EDS for flexible surfaces
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA TechPort and science.gov sources.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA TechPort and science.gov sources.

power_kw.notes: Similar to standard EDS: low power, 1-4 kV voltage
power_kw.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA TechPort and science.gov sources.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA TechPort and science.gov sources.

performance.notes: Flexible variant maintains dust removal capabilities of standard EDS
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA TechPort and science.gov sources.

items.application: Flexible surfaces, spacesuit components, deployable structures
items.notes: Bendable version of standard EDS for flexible/curved surfaces. Enables application to spacesuits and deployable systems. Flight hardware significantly miniaturized.

items.vendor: Research Consortium (University of North Dakota lead)
items.model: SPIcDER - Spacesuit Integrated Carbon nanotube Dust Ejection/Removal

mass_kg.notes: CNT fibers embedded in suit material, negligible mass addition

performance.notes: 85%+ removal of 10-75 µm particles in ambient and vacuum. Scalable to full spacesuit demonstrated on knee joint prototype

items.application: Spacesuit outer layers, flexible protective fabrics
items.notes: CNT fibers embedded in spacesuit fabric. Uses EDS principle adapted for textiles. Time-varying electric fields repel dust. Proven scalable to full suit sections. Safety considerations documented.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5. Published research 2023 in Acta Astronautica. Laboratory demonstrated with NASA grant funding.

mass_kg.notes: System mass not published, requires liquid N2 reservoir

power_kw.notes: Cryogenic storage and spray mechanism power not specified

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed research phase. Published 2023, ongoing development.

performance.notes: 98.4% in vacuum, 97% ambient. 95.9% removal of <10 µm particles. Uses Leidenfrost Effect. 75 cleaning cycles before material damage vs 1 cycle for brushing
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed 98.4% from peer-reviewed publication (Acta Astronautica 2023). 95.9% removal of <10 µm particles.

items.application: Airlock spacesuit cleaning, post-EVA dust removal
items.notes: Uses Leidenfrost Effect: liquid N2 beads up on warm suit, lifts dust particles. Minimal suit damage. Dust migrates to lowest point for collection. Better than all conventional techniques. NASA grant funded.

trl.notes: Phase II SBIR award, prototype development

power_kw.notes: No power required per design specification

performance.notes: Additive manufactured covers for venting components. Magnetic brushes for post-EVA dust removal. Geometry-specific designs for each component

items.application: xEMU spacesuit venting components protection during lunar EVA
items.notes: Southwick, Massachusetts company. PI: Thomas Stapleton. Passive covers consume no power/minimal volume. Magnetic brushes leverage dust's magnetic properties. Custom geometry for each xEMU component.

items.vendor: Brand Griffin / NASA Johnson Space Center

trl.notes: Tested in lunar gravity simulation, thermal vacuum chamber testing completed
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 7. Tested in lunar gravity simulation and thermal vacuum chamber per NASA NTRS sources.

performance.notes: Majority of suit dust remains outside habitation zone. Rear-entry design prevents dust transfer during ingress/egress
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from Wikipedia and NASA NTRS. Eliminates dust migration by keeping suit exterior to habitat.

items.application: Habitat/rover rear-entry suit access, dust containment
items.notes: Spacesuit backpack seals against vehicle exterior. Astronaut enters feet-first from pressurized environment. Tested with Z-1 suit at JSC. NASA Space Exploration Vehicle conceptual design has 2 suitports. Brand Griffin built prototype.

trl.notes: Flying on Blue Ghost 1 (2025), operational demonstration imminent
trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 8 to TRL 9. Successfully operated on lunar surface during Blue Ghost Mission 1 (landed March 2, 2025). Flight proven = TRL 9.

items.notes: Primary purpose is sample collection, not dust mitigation. Pneumatic system uses compressed gas. Included as demonstrates vacuum technology for lunar use. May have dust mitigation applications.

performance.notes: Standard HEPA: 99.97% efficiency for 0.3 µm particles. Multistage: screen (>800 µm) + internal (>5 µm) + HEPA (<5 µm). NASA standard: <10 µm particles to 0.3 mg/m³ TWA
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from NASA NTRS extensive testing documentation.

items.application: Lunar habitat air quality control, airlock filtration, crew breathing air
items.notes: Mature terrestrial technology adapted for lunar use. NASA GRC extensive testing program. Critical for crew health: 7% of lunar regolith by mass is <10 µm airborne hazard. Particles remain suspended in low gravity. Required for medical operations and long-duration habitation.

trl.notes: Space Act Agreement with NASA (Sept 2022), lunar testing on Blue Ghost
trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 6 to TRL 7. Tested on Blue Ghost Mission 1 (2025) lunar surface per Voyager press release. Operational environment demonstration = TRL 7.

performance.notes: Passive dust mitigation. Can be applied to many surfaces and components. Tested on EVA suit outer surface in RAC payload
performance.verification_notes: Confirmed from Voyager/Pioneer press releases. Passive dust repellent tested on EVA suit material on lunar surface.

items.application: xEMU spacesuit, Lunar Terrain Vehicle, pressurized rovers, habitat surfaces, general equipment
items.notes: Clear coating applied to outer surfaces. Passive method reduces technical and safety risks. Potential to transform lunar hardware operations. Commercial product with Earth applications. VP Business Development: Mike Bowker.

trl.notes: Ranked as high-scoring technology in 2022 comprehensive review, industrial product adapted for lunar use

performance.notes: Ranked alongside Lotus coating and EDS in comprehensive trade study. Physical barrier prevents dust intrusion into mechanisms, joints, and moving parts

items.application: Robotic joints, rover mechanisms, actuator protection, moving parts, flexible connections
items.notes: Industrial product adapted for lunar use. Fiberglass fabric provides dust barrier for articulating joints and mechanisms. Passive protection requires no power/electronics. Prevents dust intrusion that causes abrasion and binding. Commercial availability enables rapid deployment.
